This patient has the auscultatory findings of chronic mitral regurgitation, including a high-pitched, blowing holosystolic murmur, ending with S
This murmur is loudest at the apex. The murmur of chronic mitral regurgitation classically radiates to the left axilla and left scapular area. Although not heard in this clip, an associated S
may indicate that the regurgitant flow volume is significant or that left heart failure with reduced ejection fraction has developed.

Aortic stenosis produces a harsh, systolic crescendo-decrescendo murmur that is loudest at the right upper sternal edge. The murmur of mitral stenosis is heard during diastole at the cardiac apex. A pericardial friction rub may consist of one to three components and may be heard in systole, diastole, or both systole and diastole. The holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation is heard loudest at the lower left sternal edge, and the intensity may increase with inspiration.
